question: In mouse models of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, does depletion of tumor-associated stroma that increases intratumoral vascular density decrease the delivery and efficacy of gemcitabine chemotherapy? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The combination therapy produced a transient increase in intratumoral vascular density and intratumoral concentration of gemcitabine, leading to transient stabilization of disease.
content.source_2: In mice receiving IPI-926 with gemcitabine, depletion of tumor-associated stroma coincided with increased microvessel density but a marked reduction in intratumoral gemcitabine exposure (âˆ’40%), and disease progressed more rapidly than with gemcitabine alone.
content.source_3: We tested whether the delivery and efficacy of gemcitabine in the mice could be improved by coadministration of IPI-926, a drug that depletes tumor-associated stromal tissue by inhibition of the Hedgehog cellular signaling pathway.
content.source_4: Across orthotopic pancreatic cancer models, Hedgehog inhibition reduced fibrosis and elevated vessel density; nevertheless, objective response rates were lower and median time to progression was shorter relative to chemotherapy alone.
